author: David Maddock
title: Ronnie Moran was central to three decades of Anfield glory - he really was 'Mr Liverpool'
text:
Sometimes, it is the simplicity of the message they conveys the most powerful of meanings. 
So when Ian Rush said this morning, with a heartfelt sincerity, "RIP Mr Liverpool", it said more about the life of Ronnie Moran than any number of lengthy tributes could convey. 
The Anfield legend died this morning after a short illness, aged 83. It is a painfully sad moment for Liverpool, but for the entire football world too, because he really was a true football man. 
Moran was synonymous with the Anfield boot room. He may have been born, and lived most of his life, in a modest Crosby dwelling a short journey away from the famous old Stadium, but for this Liverpool great, that pokey cubby hole hidden under the stands was his real home. 
Many say the boot room is the spiritual home of Liverpool Football Club, and that legend was born thanks in no small part to the man who served the club for half a century as player, coach and - briefly - manager. Former Liverpool manager Kenny Dalglish celebrates 1990 title with Moran and Roy Evans (Photo: Dan Smith) The former coach, player and assistant in February last year (Photo: Nick Taylor) 
Given the romantic misting of time and history, some younger fans don't even realise the boot room was actually just that - a room without natural light barely bigger than a cupboard where the player's boots were cleaned and stored. 
It became so much more than that though, a central command where the club's coaches met informally - often without the manager - to plot Liverpool's remarkable march across Europe for the best part of three decades. 
Ronnie Moran was central to that. He was a player when Bill Shankly arrived in 1959, and became his captain, with the new manager recognising the leadership and mentality he wanted to navigate the club from second division backwaters towards the European high seas. 
Moran joined Liverpool as a 15 year old in 1949, combining his role as left back in the 'C' team with an electrician's apprenticeship, before turning professional and making his debut for the first team as an 18 year old in 1952. Moran, second from the left, back row, at Anfield in 1964 (Photo: Getty) Moran in 1991 (Photo: Mirrorpix) 
But it was the arrival of Shankly that was to change his life...and the life of every Liverpool fan across the city. Most of the players the new manager inherited were discarded because they didn't know how to be winners, according to Shanks. 
But not Moran, he helped steer the Reds back into the First Division in 1962, and was a regular member of the side that won the title two years later. 
He missed out on the FA Cup final in 1965 as his playing career drew to a close, but when his replacement at left back Gerry Byrne dislocated a shoulder, he returned to play both legs of the infamous European Cup semi final with Inter Milan. 
The away defeat under controversial circumstances - where Shankly claimed the referee was bribed and history subsequently vindicated the claim - was his last as a first team player who earned the princely sum of Â£30 a week at the peak of his career. Moran in the Anfield boot room (Photo: MPA / Trinity) Former Liveprool manager Brendan Rodgers talks to Moran at Melwood (Photo: John Powell) 
It was the decision that summer to accept Shankly's offer to become a coach at the club that took him on the road to becoming Mr Liverpool, as he so quickly fitted into the boot room culture created when Joe Fagan took a crate of Guinness in there to help the coaches relax and plan future triumphs. 
What followed was an unprecedented run of success, with Moran serving under Shankly, Bob Paisley, Fagan, Kenny Dalglish, Graeme Souness and Roy Evans, before retiring in 1999, after two spells as a caretaker manager...a role he insisted he never wanted permanently. 
He was always known as the 'bad cop' who kept the players' feet on the ground, even as they were reaching for the stars. But Moran was far more than that, a driven coach who pressed his players to improve, and never be satisfied with their latest triumph. 
He was Mr Liverpool. The thread between the doldrum days of the second division and the greatest European nights of all. He was, as Robbie Fowler said "a man who not only had Liverpool in his blood, but WAS the lifeblood of Liverpool." 
Perhaps the biggest tribute of all though, is that Ronnie Moran will be remembered forever at Liverpool Football Club. Like us on Facebook
